16945365.review:
Darkest Hour es un juego soberbio. Para mi sin duda el que mejor recrea el turbulento siglo XX, por encima incluso de Hearts of Iron III y todas sus expansiones -que las tengo-. Siendo los dos juegos bastante buenos, Darkest Hour le supera por estar mucho más vivo y ser menos plano. 

En Darkest Hour dispondrás de las dos guerras mundiales, y además para aquellos que hayan jugado este mismo tipo de juegos en "tableros" -supongo la mayoría- es mucho más bonito que otros. Convengan conmigo que no es lo mismo jugar con marcadores estadísticos, que estos mismos apoyados con uniformes, composición material de las divisiones, que son los equipos de trabajo.... Todo lo podrás visualizar sin necesidad de imaginar. 

Esta es la diferencia que a mi modo de ver, hace que Darkest Hour, basado en un mod de Hearts of Iron II, sea superior que Hearts of Iron III. En la investigación y el árbol tecnologico te sientes absorvido, y comprendes rápido que nación es una potencia y cual un país sin posibilidades. Por más que quieras, sin trucos, editores, ni trampas, una pequeña nación seguirá siendo una pequeña nación... Suficiente si sobrevive a la vorágine. 

La única ventaja palpable de Hearts of Iron III es su división del mapa. Al ser más fraccionado, permite militarmente una estrategia "divisionaria" y de maniobra estupenda, cosa que aquí en Hearts of Iron, tendrás que basar en un uso más de Grupo de Ejércitos. Esto evidentemente no lastra la experiencia, que incluso se vuelve más simplificada y a veces comprensible, pero reconozco que no te deja explotar al máximo tus capacidades envolventes... Con todo cuando logras copar un Grupo de 6 divisiones -o más- en una bolsa, te sientes como el Ejercito Rojo en Stalingrado a punto de machacar al VI Grupo de Ejércitos... 

Los combates de Hearts of Iron III me aburren sustancialmente. Por contra, aquí, verás las bajas, que están perdiendo, ya sea vehículos, animales, personal, la artillería, y absoutamente todo. Maravilloso ver como una división de infantería, al motorizarse, comienza a reducir su componente animal por vehículos y blindados. Al igual que cuando lanzas un ataque de aviación naval, o combate naval simplemente, ves como una escuadra de destructores o cañoneras, pierden 2, 3, 4 unidades en la sorpresa y emboscada... 

Las fichas de juego son las propias de mapas estratégicos, pero al pulsarlas verás uniformidades y vehículos apropiados... No es lo mismo la infantería del 26, que la de 1936... Además de mejorar estadísticamente las capacidades, verás su aspecto real. Antes mencioné la investigación, y por supuesto, se hace muy atrayente. Verás las empresas, estudiosos, universidades de cada país, al servicio de la nación, comprendiendo que puede ir bien o mal. Hearts of Iron III tiene un sistema cogido con dos pinzas... Cuando lo comprendes dices... Ah vale... Pero nada más... 

Como botón de muestra de las posibilidades, suelo jugar con España Nacional -cojo la partida 1936 con la república, espero unos meses sin afectar en las producciones ni habilidades de esta, cuando comienza la guerra civil, que empezará, grabo, salgo, y comienzo seleccionando los "franquistas"- y en la última que estoy realizando, aliado con el Eje, Gibraltar tomado -con muchísimas bajas por cierto-, avanzando en terrible pinza latina por el territorio argelino-tunecino frente a tropas británicas allí estacionadas, a punto de su colapso con el aliado italiano.... Y un desembarco maravilloso de los aliados en italia -estratégicamente perfecto a mi modo de ver, pues con España e Italia en un sobresfuerzo bélico africano, y descuidadas las defensas propias de ambas naciones- los italianos colapsan gubernativamente -como les ocurrió- y se rinden de repente.... Imaginen mi cara. A punto de vencer a los británicos en bona y túnez, la falta de la presión italiana complica mucho mi situación. Alemania está muy lejos y enfrascada en una durísima y paralizada campaña de rusia, y ahora los británicos avanzan su VIII ejercito en pleno desde la linea de la Cirenaica hacia Tunez... Evidentemente he comenzado una retirada total al tener desperdigados mis grupos, esperando proteger la linea montañosa del Atlas marroquí, que estoy tratando de fortificar, pues es mucho más defendible que la estirada linea del Sahara-Argelia. Evidentemente tengo muy malos augurios si sobrepasan esa linea o se deciden al desembarco peninsular -cosa que estoy esperando-.... 

10/10 estupendo.

16609652.review:
I was playing as the Nazi Germans, and was in the fight of my life against the soviet union, playing on Hard. My Army Group South's advance was stalling out, and I couldn't break the Soviet Defenses around Leningrad. Army Group north was closing in on moscow, but the feirce winter had my troops stuck in their tracks. Hoping to avoid Hitler's folly, I had build up winter equipment for my men prior to the invasion, but however these extra insulated uniforms and felt boots haven't done much to increase my chances of sucess. After just losing a key battle on my way towards Moscow I decided to pan down to North Africa. Here I had blitzed through the British Lines with my Italian allies, however it was becoming more apparent that we were going to be surrounded at the suez cannal. However I just had to hold the province long enough for my fleet of troop transports to go through the cannal and escape the mediteranian sea, where they would then drop reinforcements off in Somalia to bolster the failing Italian defensive lines. Then It happened. Out of no where the English navy blindly stubles into my fleet of unarmed troop transports and they sink every single one of them. Eight Divisons, a total of 104,000 Soldiers died at sea because of my blunder! I then saved my game and decided to pick it back up later. After just getting off the game, It hit me that I've been playing this amazing game for so long, and never publically voiced my opinion about it, so I decided I'd give this game and the developers, the credit it deserves. 

I have to say this is by hard my favorite grand strategy games of all time. The gameplay allows for endless possibilities such as alternate historical events and outcomes. The events triggered in the game catter to shaping a world that you desire. The game also has a plethora of many great Mods for it, such as "The Grand Campaign" which bridges the World War 1 Sencario with the World War II scenario, allowing you to start in the year 1914 and end in 1991. I've spent about 212 Hours playing this game on steam, however I've easily spent another 400 playing this game on Multiplayer via Game Ranger, which at the moment is the only way to play this game with your Friends, however it does not launch the game through steam. Not only will you being scultpting the world, but you also learn a great deal about history and geopraghy at the same time. This ultra realistic diplomacy, political, and war simulator will, Darkest Hour a Hearts of Iron game, will always hold a special place in my heart, and I do not think Hearts of Iron IV will even be able to top Darkest Hour. 


My Favorite Strategy Game ever! Totally worth the buy! If you have it and are discouraged, don't give up, once you learn how to play this game you can have so so so much endless fun with it!

Wonderful wargame (only $1.99!  Wow!), without the bugs of HOI2, that permits you to take control of any nation during WWII (and a limited WWI) and play out just about any hypothetical historical situation that you desire.  Want to try to strangle Japan with your Australian wolfpacks?  No problem.  Want to sign South Africa up with the Axis and drive the British back across the equator?  No problem.  Want to form Greater Argentina by swallowing up Paraguay and all of your other little neighbors while the USA (hopefully) isn't looking?  No problem.
I am currently playing Italy and so far:
- I reformed into a paternal autocracy under the King and hit the mute button on Mussolini
- Cranked my IC up to 135 with all tech slots available
- Focused on a maritime & aeronautics strategy in line with Italy's best techs
- Stayed neutral during WWII in order to satisfy my own selfish imperialist greed
- Formed a Mediterranean Bloc with Portugal, Spain, Greece and Bulgaria to support said greed
- launched 6 Italian carrier battle-groups to keep the Germans out of Mare Nostrum, with more on the way
- Blockaded the Persian Gulf and slogged my way, yard by bloody yard through the oil fields of Iran with 7 marine divisions and 3 mountain divisions in reserve to feed my thirsty industry
- Said marine and mountain divisions are now knocking back cappuchinos in the Shah's Tea Room in Tehran
- I am now preparing for the real possibility of a general war between the Italian and Japanese Empires along the Indus River If Japan continues its leisurely stroll west through the British Raj.
Well done, well done!  *sips a cappuchino*

16009977.review:
I played many hours and many campaigns in HoI ages ago and enjoyed it. I hoped to enjoy DH: HoIG as well, but really couldn't.

Why?

1. 
The advantage of HoI was that you could do alternate history, changing the course of events, etc. DH pretty much forces you into a very pre-determined course. I tried playing as Yugoslavia, 1936 and in spite of beefing up an army, fortifying borders, doing my best to stay out of the coming war, having excellent relations with Germany, Italy, etc, come 1941, scripted ultimatum by Germany, your choices are "become a puppet" - game over or "be invaded" - game over. 

Tried playing as the Soviets, HoI gave you a choice "do Stalin's purges, lose a third of your generals" or "don't do purges, see your dissent skyrocket". DH gives you no choice, purges just happen, you lose a third of your generals AND your dissent skyrockets (weird actually, since the purges had a rather opposite effect, putting everyone in line with the dictator's commands). 

So, basically the player has very little freedom of action, outside of the developers vision of how a scenario should play out. This, to me, defeats the purpose of a sandbox grand strategy game...

2. 
Bias or unbalance. I got a distinct feeling the game was very pro-Germany biased. I tried a 1933 Soviet scenario and tried to play a "nice Stalin" one that helps and liberates, rather than opresses. Got involved in the Spanish civil war, took over the troops, helped Republicans get a clean win. And the thanks for my effort? Minimal relations increase, no alliance, a puny 1% dissent decrease (but for changing a minister I ger a 2% dessent increase), no military experience, basically nothing. 

Got involved with the Chinese in fighting off the Japanese invasion, by inviting Commie China into an alliance. Automatically Nationalist China also becomes an ally. I soundly beat the Japs, annex Chinese territory which automatically transfers to (should at least ask me which China I wanna give it to) Nationalist China. Japan asks for peace giving all Chinese territory back and Korea and Pacific islands too. I accept, Nationalist China becomes huge, but both Chinas immediately break off the alliance with me and go into negative relations. I immediately liberate Korea, but my belligerence goes up. I get no option to liberate Pacific islands and am forced to give them to Korea if I don't want rebellions. 

I don't give any ultimatums or invade Finland, but they still hate my guts and try to assasinate my ministers. And French and British keep trying to assasinate my ministers. I don't accept Hitler's pact to divide Poland, but he still invades it, just instead of getting half of it, he gets all of it. My belligerence is still in its 70s just for helping liberate China without keeping a single province to myself, while German one after invading the entire Europe is in its 50s. 

I fortify my western border with bunkers, behind rivers, upgrade all my troops to latest level, research nothing but land tactics, beefing up my ground forces to latest standard of warfare, got 1941 tanks in 1939, good and skilled generals in command. No good. When the Nazi decides to invade, he's got at least 100 divisions more than me and in spite having lower organisational rating, still cuts through my lines like a hot knife through butter. 

Oh, and Lend-Lease. US sent over 20,000 tanks and airplanes to the Soviets. What does DH game give me? Not a single tank or plane, but 50 units of roads instead. 

3. 
Airforce is entirely useless. When the Nazi invades, I got complete air dominance (his planes are likely over Britain). I pound an advancing column with my entire airforce of 4 Tactical bomber groups, 4 close-air-support groups and 12 fighter squadrons all in their latest 1941 upgrades. And all I kill is 400 enemy men out of 100,000, practically don't even scratch them. No organisational disruption. No advancement slow down. Nothing. All money spent on (expensive) airforce is completely wasted.

4. 
Diplomacy. Pretty useless. Any alliances, non-aggression pacts, demanding territory, outside of scripted ones are practically impossible to achieve. 

5. 
Intelligence. Pretty useless. Chances for any actions are so low and so expensive, that the money is utterly wasted on them and coups, sabotages, etc are practically impossible or if they happen they're definitely not worth the money in the minimal effect they have.

I suppose the only way to have a chance is to invest everything in a thousand infantry divisions with artillery attachments and all the money into research boosts so you get blueprints for stuff every time. All the other features are useless and a waste of time. I'm a stubborn person, so I tried same scenarios several times, trying to make some optimal decisions to enable me to gain the upper hand, but the game just keeps blocking any progress I make by its punishing mechanics, limiting diplomacy and disruptive random events. Maybe I should just play as Germany and steamroll everyone.

Verdict: Forced. Unbalanced. Biased. Frustrating. Unrewarding. Punishing. Irrational.

本作は第二次大戦期を題材としたHearts of Iron 2（通称HoI2）の完全版とでもいうべき作品である。
「え？HoI2ってコンプリート版あるじゃん？」
そう思った人もいるかもしれないが、なんとHoI2のコンプリート版（通称DDA）と本作のnoneモードはほぼ一緒なのである。

そのnoneに加えて、新要素によるやりごたえ十分のfullと、その2つの中間のlightとで、合わせて3つのモードで遊べる。
さらに言えば動作の軽量化や、MOD導入の簡便化や、操作性の向上など多くの改善がなされている。
なのにコンプリート版は¥ 1,480で本作は¥ 980である。 

DLCを抜いて遊びたいだとか、マルチ対戦のために友達とバージョンをあわせる必要性があるとか、DDAとのちょっとした違いが気になるなどの理由がなければ、本作の購入をオススメする。

15615811.review:
Like any game of Paradox that is based on it's more older engines, it has a learning curve. 

My main reasons for recommending this game:
[b] Mods [/b]
Kaiserreich : http://cs.servegame.com/kaiserreich/. They even have their own forum, although they also have the mod on the paradox forum, but you can't see that unless you register the game. Anyway, apart from the Kaisserreich mods there is an enormous variety of excellent mods that far outstrips any other WW II game that Paradox or other developers have produced. This game has excellent moddability.

[b] Strategy [/b]
The strategy in this game is excellent, although the economy side is a little underdeveloped compared to Arsenal of Democracy. The strategy in this game with the available missions on land, air and sea far outstrips anything other games can represent. 

[b] AI [/b]
The AI is competent, the AI will destroy you if you don't follow your plan. If you deviate too often from your set plan the AI will absolutely destroy you since they are competent at doing the missions. The ability to control your puppets or the smaller countries in your alliance makes up for any incompetence they might present. The expeditionary forces ability gives you the ability to help your ally in need without the hassle of controlling them yourselves.

[b] Tech teams [/b]
The number of tech teams is based on your Industrial Capacity, this means the more IC the more tech teams. The tech teams are a better alternative than the HOI3 model of just leadership points. The techteams have certain areas where they are competent in and the level determines how good they are. This means that some nations have an edge in some areas of research.

15499152.review:
This game deserves better reviews than the "11/10 would [insert stupid joke here] again" nonsense.

Most reviews assume that you have played Hearts of Iron II before.  I never have, so jumping into this game was one of the most daunting things I've ever done when playing a video game.  Seriously, I've taken college courses that were easier than learning how to play Darkest Hour.  There's a ton of things to understand if you're going to be successful.  If you think I'm exaggerating, get this: the manual is 158 PAGES LONG.  On top of that, there are not many Let's Play videos of Darkest Hour on YouTube, and there are even fewer good ones.  There are not many people on the forum, but the few people there are very helpful.

In short, learning this game as a newbie is going to be a steep uphill battle.  This game will punish you for forgetting to click a certain button or set a certain slider.  There are tons of little details and the interface is pretty hard to navigate.

HOWEVER, this game is like a dream come true for someone like me, who has always loved reading about the 20th century and has always wondered what would have happened if Germany won WWI, if Japan attacked the Soviet Union instead of the United States, if Spain joined the Axis and attacked Gibraltar, etc.  The complexity of this game makes all the potential outcomes much more plausible, and therefore more entertaining.  And there's nothing like looking through the divisions you're commanding and finding the one your grandfather served in.

tl;dr: this game is HARD.  Learning it will take many hours.  I'm not even close to mastering this game.  However, it's well worth the effort.  Winning a multiplayer match on any of your shooters isn't nearly as satisfying as winning a hard fought war and changing the world.

15445913.review:
Первое знакомство с серией Hearts of Iron случилось у меня много лет назад, ещё в середине 2000-х. Заболел моментально! 
Рекомендую всем к покупе. Главные доводы: 
- Вам надоели эти все скучные и унылые игры, которые вы проходите раз за разом и потом оставляете их "на полке", больше к ним не возвращаясь? 
- У вас богатое воображение и вам кажется, что почему бы не стать во главе какой-нибудь страны в Южной Америке и своими небольшими действиями на континенте коренным образом повлиять на ход событий перед Второй мировой войной. 
- Вы довольно образованы и у вас широкий кругозор, вы понимаете базовые основы геополитики и знаете довольно банальные ответы, как - "для чего нам захватывать территорию Азербайджана или зону Персидского залива, небольшую область Румынии (если вы вдруг играете за Германию), для чего вам нужны ключевые проливы в Средиземном море и для чего их контролировать, вы неплохо знаете историю и глядя на дату можете принять то или иное ключевое решение (например - подготовиться заранее к вторжению Германии в СССР) или изменить ход Зимней войны.
- Вы понимаете, что лучше прорывать фронт противника танковыми дивизиями во взаимодействии с моторизованными и механизированными, а пехотными дивизиями лучше уничтожать окруженные войска противника. 

И пр. пр. пр. 

В дополнении к этому вы можете добавить к игре большое количество модов, сценариев - от реалистичных до более альтернативных и фантастических (встречал даже нашествие инопланетян). 

Сетевые игры тоже частенько увлекают надолго, особенно если играть в компании хороших друзей и единомышленников. 

Минусы? 
- Иногда становится скучно прокручивать даты, пока в мире тишина и спокойствие, войн нет, а экономика развивается, вы строите флот/пехоту/ракеты и исследуете новые технологии. Но этого времени хватает обычно на перебазирование войск и создание новых подразделений.
- Хотелось бы побольше ивентов (решается модами).

15311330.review:
Darkest Hour es sin duda, ¡es uno de los Mejores Juegos de Estrategia!

¿Por que?  Ahora te voy a explicar mis razones:

+  Puedes jugar  la 1ª Guerra Mundial, la 2ª Guerra Mundial, la Guerra Fria o que continues infinitamente con tu país.
+  Podemos usar cualquier nación, de los cientos que hay.
+ Cuando tengamos el país que queramos, le controlaremos: la política, el ejercito y la economia.
 Una estupenda banda sonora.
+ Provocar la destruccion Mundial.
+ Miles de fotos de los politicos y generales que mandaban en su época.
+ Sucesos en el que tendremos que elegir una opción, aveces puede provocar una guerra o una alianza. O también bonus en suministros, dinero o mejoras en los enfrentamientos.
+ Dependiendo de la ideologia de tu país, quizas te alies con unos u otros. Además hará que tengas ventajas en los apartados de tu nación (mayor producción, facilidad para comerciar, etc)
+ Las batallas pueden ser terrestres, navales o aéreas. Por eso, tendrás que producir unidades de los tres tipos y mejorar la tecnología para mantenerte a la altura de los demás paises.
+ Si investigas mucho en "Tecnología", podras realizar bombas atómicas. Causando muchas bajas y destrucción.
+ Cuando conquistes un país, puedes, quedarte su territorio o que sea tu aliado (estado títere). Los estados títere vienen bien si los ciudadanos de esas zonas son muy rebeldes y no dispones de soldados para reprimirlos.
+ Multijugador para más de 8 personas.
+ Gráficamente no esta mal, graficos sencillos y agradables. Pero en la actualidad, si eres de los que buscan lo mejorcito, este se queda bastante desfasado.
+ Funciona en cualquier ordenador. Yo lo jugaba con un ordenador que como mucho funcionaba el Counter Strike 1.6
+ El mapa es gigantesco, tendrá más de 1500 provincias. Preparate si tienes ambiciones de conquistar todo el mundo, porque tardarás días.
+ Sistema de combate sencillo y además, salen cuantas bajas han ocurrido en la batalla. En las batallas hay diversos factores que producen efectos positivos o negativos en los enfrentamientos. Por ejemplo, luchar en lugares donde haya barro reducirá la movilidad de las tropas atacantes o pelear en montañas ofrece un plus en defensa para las unidades que estén defendiendo.
+ La dificultad es modificable, podemos hacer que la IA sea más complicada o que nuestro nivel de producción sea menor.
+ Tutorial que te enseña a jugar un poquito. Aunque yo no lo utilicé, yo aprendí a la par que jugaba mi primera partida (que perdí, jajaja)
+ Aparición de partisanos, esto le da un toque más realista al juego. Salen cuando los ciudadanos están descontentos con las acciones tomadas por sus governantes. Intentarán conquistar el mayor número de territorios, pero suelen ser muy debiles. 
+ ¡Incluye Hearts of Iron II con sus dos expansiones! Con lo que te ahorrarás una pasta.
+ En definitiva, un juego de estrategia profundo.


Tras contar una infinidad de las cosas buenas de Darkest Hour, toca decir algo "malo", aunque,para mi, malo, no hay casi nada:

- Si eres un pais pequeño, poco podras hacer (con Luxenburgo...). Aunque esto como problema no lo diría, porque es así. Si eres una nación pequeña, producirás menos, con lo que tendrás un ejercito menor y por tanto, tendrás una participación menor.

- Un poco de dificultad para organizar una partida online.


Bueno si has llegado hasta aqui, enhorabuena, te recomiendo al 100% comprar este juego, eso sí, te tiene que gustar la estrategia. 
Mi valoración: 9,75

14961934.review:
Dont know what to write, so I will write a recipie for pancakes.

ingredients

100g plain flour
2 eggs
300ml semi-skimmed milk
1 tbsp sunflower oil or vegetable, plus extra for frying
pinch salt

Method

Blending in the flour: Put the flour and a pinch of salt into a large mixing bowl and make a well in the centre. Crack the eggs into the middle, then pour in about 50ml milk and 1 tbsp oil. Start whisking from the centre, gradually drawing the flour into the eggs, milk and oil. Once all the flour is incorporated, beat until you have a smooth, thick paste. Add a little more milk if it is too stiff to beat.
Finishing the batter: Add a good splash of milk and whisk to loosen the thick batter. While still whisking, pour in a steady stream of the remaining milk. Continue pouring and whisking until you have a batter that is the consistency of slightly thick single cream. Traditionally, people would say to now leave the batter for 30 mins, to allow the starch in the flour to swell, but there’s no need.
Getting the right thickness: Heat the pan over a moderate heat, then wipe it with oiled kitchen paper. Ladle some batter into the pan, tilting the pan to move the mixture around for a thin and even layer. Quickly pour any excess batter into a jug, return the pan to the heat, then leave to cook, undisturbed, for about 30 secs. Pour the excess batter from the jug back into the mixing bowl. If the pan is the right temperature, the pancake should turn golden underneath after about 30 secs and will be ready to turn.
Flipping pancakes: Hold the pan handle, ease a fish slice under the pancake, then quickly lift and flip it over. Make sure the pancake is lying flat against base of the pan with no folds, then cook for another 30 secs before turning out onto a warm plate. Continue with the rest of the batter, serving them as you cook or stack onto a plate. You can freeze the pancakes for 1 month, wrapped in cling film or make them up to a day ahead.

When I first got this game, I was dissapointed, I didn't know how to play, and it was one of those games with Essayd for Tutorials. I gave it a few goes, and immediately regretted my purchase. However, after trying again and again, I played my first few campaigns and it was great. Now, by using the Grand Campaign Mod, I was able to command any nation from 1914-1991, I chose Italy. 
The War began, and, instead of leaving the Central Powers like in History, I decided that Italy shall remain. The Great War broke out, and I fought combat on many fronts, such as Africa (In which some Jihadists and the UK and French kicked me out), the Franco-Italian border (Made no Progress whatsoever), and the Expeditionary forces I sent to Austria Hungary to fight Serbia (Also no progress). My action caused the War to end early, in 1917, and as such:
 -Germany never made the full advance into Russia, which, in turn, STOPPED THE RUSSIAN REVOLUTION. 
 -Austria-Hungary Still Existed
 -The Central Powers and Triple Entete still exist
 By 1920, I had made Italy a dictatorship, and modernised it's military, now rising to almost Germany's Level of Power. Bulgaria and the Ottomans had given me Military Command of their army. 
The Game is still going on. 

Basically, everything you do can change history, yes, you can stick to history, but why not see what you can accomplish with knowledge of what you can prevent? 

10/10

13980133.review: Even outdated this is one the bestestestestest games ever if you don't mind sitting around idle pondering and organizing.The base game has campaigns in WW1 and WW2 where you can lead any country on earth pretty much,even like Tannu Tuva(based tannu tuva)or Nepal.Unfortunately by default the interwar period is not interesting,there is a mod called the grand campaign which supposedly fixes it but I've never really got it to work properly which is a shame.Which gets me to the real greatness of this game:the modding community!!There are so many great mods that will allow you to play in all these different time frames and scenarios with the same polish and fun of the base game pretty much.There are mods that improve the base campaign(total realism,world in flames,mod33,etc)mods that are set in other time periods(modern day scenario,new world order 2(cold war),even napoleonic wars)and mods that COMPLETELY CHANGE THE TIMELINE into a ahistorical one which are my favourites like Kaiserreich(germany wins ww1)abd even a mod that let's you play in the wastelands of the fallout universe!!The only problem is the game is really showing it's age and doesn't work great on new OSs and the engine doesn't allow for much more to be done with it than it already has,so we are just left to hope hearts of iron 4 improves on boring overcomplicated soulless hearts of iron 3,which doesn't involve you into the experience of leading a fucking war one single bit in my opinion.

13682240.review: Darkest Hour: a Hearts of Iron Game is a Grand Strategy game made by Paradox Interactive. The HOI series as a whole are about World War II. Darkest Hour (DH) is no exeption. The difference time-wise in DH is not only does it cover WWII, it also covers WWI, as the timeline stretches from june 27, 1914, through 1961, if you start in 1933, or even 1974, if you start in 1945. WWI something I definately don't see in many video games, grand strategy or not. DH revolves around warfare, so it is very importnt to keep a strong standing army throughout the game. At multiple times as I played Germany, France found it necessary to declare war on me very early on in the game when I played in a WWII scenario. Germany's army is very small and has a very small amount of manpower if you start in 1933 or 1936, 1939 and 1940 aren't so bad at first, and I haven't started in 1941, '42, '43 '44, or '45 yet, but I would imagine '45 is pretty bad. Back to the army, not only is it important to keep a large one, but it should be as updated as possibe, if you're at war and your enemy is leagues ahead of you in technology, you can be sure to lose a boatload of soldiers no matter what.

Que dire que dire à propos de ce jeux?^^

Tout d'abord, pour les fans d'histoire, vous allez être servi. On retrouve tous les éléments historique d'avant-pendant-après guerre mais pas toujours au bon moment.

Ensuite, le jeux n'est pas gourmand. Normal, ce jeux se présente sous la forme d'un Risk (le jeux de socièté) avec quelques petites particularités que je vous laisses découvrir.

Pour ce qui est du temps de vie, c'est difficile à dire car j'avais déjà jouer une cinquantaine d'heures avant de me rendre compte que je faisais de la m.... donc, j'en ai recommencé une autre où actuellement, j'ai commencer en 1933 et qui est actuellement en 1956 pour 60H de jeux.

Le choix des nations est bien fournie, ce qui vous permettra de passer un très long moment dessus mais, même si on à beaucoup de nation à disposition, il peut s'avèrer difficile de jouer certaines car face aux 4 géants du jeux (Allemand,Russe,Américain et Anglais), il vous faudra jouer finement ^^

Vous avez aussi un choix dans votre date de départ (1933-1936-1939-1940-1941-1942-1943-1944-1945).

Enfin, ce jeux est founis avec un ou deux modes, ce qui vous permettra d'augmenter encore un peu votre temps de jeux

En conclusion, un bon jeux pas gourmand, bien fournis, bien travailler et qui mérite sa place dans votre bibliothèque, pas comme WatchDogs ;)

12380204.review:
Darkest Hour is definitely a better HoI game than HoI3, despite its age. There's no unnecessarily complex OoB system that you'd need to graduate West Point to master, there aren't a billion shapeless provinces in sparsely populated areas, and although the map and UI are pretty dated they're comfy to use. In contrast to the dryness of HoI3 which has maybe half a dozen decisions solely for the purpose of railroading the AI into doing what it's supposed to do, DH has plenty of dynamic event chains, and it feels like you're really impacting the world. DH also has more of a sandboxy feel to it, with different outcomes every game, but in HoI3 once you've played each of the 3 factions you've more or less experienced it all. Then there's the timespan, with a grand campaign in DH potentially lasting from 1914-1964, 50 years, compared to 1936-1948, or 12 years, in HoI3. And last, but definitely not least, DH is tremendously easier to mod than HoI3, and so has a very active and skilled modding community. Which brings me to my last point:

Kaiserreich: Legacy of the Weltkrieg. The amount of detail put into this alternate-history mod for Darkest Hour is pretty stunning, and is definitely a justification all on its own for buying the game. If you have even a slight interest in alt-history, you'd be doing yourself a huge favor by picking this up and installing KR.

The base game is easily a 9/10, but Kaiserreich bumps that up to a 10/10.

This might be the best grand strategy ever.

Great gameplay.

11775353.review: This is a must have game for anyone that enjoys playing strategic simulators based on the 20th century. It's basically a revamped Hearts of Iron 2 but it is very well done. Plus there is many mods from the Paradox Interactive Forums that allow a lot of scenarios and replayability such as Kaiserreich or New World Order. 11759196.review: Although I admit it's not for everyone, if you are a strategy fan or looking to get into strategy, this is a must have. The learning curve is very high, so read all of the tips and complete all tutorials before starting. It may be tedious, but trust me, it's better than playing the game incompetently for several months like I did. Once you get the hang of it, the game will be extremely fun and almost dangerously addictive, so beware. There is almost endless replayability value, and I have not even completed a full campaign as all of the major powers yet, even with 400+ hours invested. There are also many excellent mods for the game, most notably the Kaiserreich: Legacy of the Weltkrieg alternate history mod, which will give you more interesting scenarios to play through. The gameplay is very immersive and much detail is put into battles and diplomacy. There is also no shortage of challenge, so even experienced players on normal difficulty will have to constantly think. The technology and economy systems are also well done. Some criticisms are the lack of diversity actually required in your armies, something fixed in HOI 3. You can often win by just building countless infantry units and simply overwhelming the enemy. There are no combined arms bonuses, and often times, using aircraft during battles or to bomb cities seemed pointless. The AI is good in most areas, but AI concerning diplomacy could improve. Making peace extremely difficult in many situations, and even if you have completely occupied an enemy country, they can still reject peace treaties, and you are forced to annex them as a result. Other than that, I experienced few problems with the game. Once again, I highly recommend it.

11608447.review:
It's pretty much the most in-depth WW2 strategy game ever conceived of. Manage diplomacy, production, upgrades, reinforcements, technological advancement, military deployments and fight the biggest war in history.

To be completely 100% honest the game is mostly a Germany Curbstomps The Earth simulator. The game is challenging and enjoyable with clear goals defineable by you or the nation you choose. Basically, Germany can choose NOT to start the war. Or it can do so much earlier. However there's a mostly 99% chance that as other countries, war will visit you in a semi-historical fashion. As USA you will be attacked by Japan in 1940-1941, and as any country but Germany there's no chance that the Germans WON'T invade.

As fun as this game is, I feel like it's seriously limiting sometimes. I've played the game for 800 hours and I still don't understand all the mechanics, but that's my fault (and let's face it, a hopelessly convoluted Naval Model for the ship combat doesn't help either). The limitations set in when you try to completely alter history. The game is designed to facilitate historical outcomes until the war starts; as a result Germany is stronger than Poland when things go down, and the Germans will have success in France and maybe even the UK. However Germany AI never really does well against the Russians, and usually by 1942 you're dealing with Communist France.

The entire game is basically designed to be played by one of the major belligerents. If you choose to play as a minor territorial expansion and leapfrogging to greatness is possible, but extremely difficult and time-consuming. Leading Cuba to conquer the Central Americas took 20+ years. The game starts in 1936, and my first invasion kicked off sometime in the late 40's.

The game is extremely complex and is basically an OCD person's worst nightmare. You'll spend hours just organizing and planning offensives before they even begin, and keeping it all organized as you advance is the real challenge. It's too easy to forget about a unit you sent that way only to read they were encircled and destroyed; the scale is such that you can suffer serious information overload.

Also, lots and LOTS of info. Constantly being relayed to the player. 

I recommend this game but with a HUGE caveat:
- If you're not super into the strategies and tactics of maneuvering armies in WW2, but are more interested in the small scale, I suggest other games. The entirety of this game is played through a map of the world. Units are represented in terms of 15,000 men instead of squads of 4 like in some RTS games set in this period. 

- If you don't like micromanagement, then avoid this game. Micromanagement is part and parcel of the experience.

- If you don't have patience then I'd avoid it as well. This is a game with a learning curve that is more or less a straight cliff. You absolutely MUST read the manual and play the game multiple times before you can understand how to play well. My first game as Germany, the Polish occupied Berlin. It's also a very time-consuming game. I call 5-6 days of continuous play a "quick playthrough" - games can often last upwards of weeks or even months. 

This is the best WW2 Grand Strategy game available, but it's also not very user friendly. Those without the patience to learn how to play should avoid this game.

11150297.review:
Darkest Hour is one of my favourite games, hands down. but why? I think I will list them in bullet points to make it simple
-Compared to HOI III it is much less complex and much, much easier to follow
-Graphically compared to HOI II it is a massive improvement. However, I also think that compared to HOI III it looks much better, but thats just my opinion, you should look at screenshots if graphics are important to you

-I find the game to be Historically accurate, with interesting scenarios that can happen, caused by the player or sometimes not caused by the player at all. 

-The WWI senario also has an interesting amount of choices which no matter who you're playing as will have an interesting affect to the game as a whole, and are plausible

-The WW2 scenario is pretty good though I always want to think of alternate events that can happen etc. etc. and there are certainly some missed oppertunities, but nothing major. 

-Mods, firstly the AAR mod, which gives the player an extended timeline from 1914 until 1964

-Mod33 a French mod that gives new nations, new events, new units, new desicions, it is a very good mod, however the event text is in French, so it is also a way to practice your French

-Modern Day scenario, a very good mod, as it says you get a modern day scenario, with all new techs, all new Units, and a load of new events, not to mention all new leaders, 

-And Finally Kaisrreich, firstly no 2 Kaiserreich games are the same, they always turn out different, in one the USA becomes Syndicalist (no communists), in another the Qing Empire re-unite China, in another game you might see an independent Siberia, chanes are you will see many of these in a single game, you might also see none

-Kaiserreich is an extremely interesting scenario, the Central Powers win WW1 and you believe that scenario, in fact it is done so well, to the point where I remember someone on the forums saying "I don't play Kaiserreich that often, but when I do, I forget real History"

9718196.review:
I am going to be honest with you.

This game has stolen many, many hours of my life. I have changed the course of History in an infinite number of ways, and have played most nations, from Germany to the USSR to Cuba to Portugal. It is the best 20th century (until 1950, anyway) grand strategy game in existence. It is far better than Hearts of Iron III.

But what is just fantastic about this game is two things: the community and the mods.

The community is one of the greatest, best bunch of history maniacs and armchair generals I have ever seen. Going to the forums is a rare and wonderful experience. And they are exceedingly nice. And they will advise you and help you. And they will discuss intricate, microscopic details of historical events with you. And you will learn. And you will like it. And you will make friends. A fantastic bunch of people.

The mods, as if the game didn't have enough content already, are incredibly fun to play, and some are incredibly detailed as well. They are not that difficult to install, and you will have a ton of fun with them. I personnally recommend Kaiserreich (Germany wins WWI) and New World Order 2 (get to play during the Cold War as well, including alternative history events for a German victory in WWII). And, of course, the community has also dedicated itself to these mods, especially Kaiserreich.

I have been playing strategy games since Civilization (the first one), and this is the best strategy game I have ever played. Period. If you like strategy games, it is a must own.

8863880.review:
ストラテジーゲームを楽しみたいという方なら強くお勧めしたい一本です。


[b]Darkest Hour[/b]
DHは[url=store.steampowered.com/app/22130/]HoI2[/url]の開発終了に伴って放出されたEurope Engineをもとに構築された、いわばHoI2の亜種ですが、新たな開発チームによる膨大なバグ取りや新要素の追加、面倒な操作の自動化やUIの改良によってよりよいものに仕上がっています。
このゲームは戦争に特化したストラテジーゲームで、武力をもって生き残ることを目標とします。資源や労働力を割り振って軍隊を建設し、それを移り変わる戦局でどう活用するかが勝利の鍵となります。そのため内政要素はほとんどなく、あってもそれは戦争の道具でしかありません。


[b]緻密に作られたゲームシステム[/b]
優れた点はやはり賢いAIでしょう。突出した部隊や、強襲上陸をかける部隊にはワラワラと集まって包囲をかけてきます。制空権・制海権の奪取を怠ると、すかさず爆撃・砲撃によって手痛い被害をうけます。兵力の配置が十分でない地域を敵軍は目ざとく発見し、そこから浸透されて戦線はいとも容易く崩壊、あなたの国の地図は簡単に塗り替えられてしまうでしょう。戦争シーンは文字通り手に汗握る展開で、油断は許されません。

次に素晴らしい音楽の存在です。全篇クラシックで壮大な音楽、戦争時・平時と雰囲気の異なったものが途切れることなく流れ続け、雰囲気を盛り上げます。サウンドトラックがはじめからゲームデータに内包されていて、いつでも聴くことができるのが隠れた魅力です。

他にも豊富なMOD(残念ながらリンク切れ・ファイル消失がちらほら)やイベント・ifシナリオなど、書ききれないほどの濃厚な要素が含まれています。それでいて容量は軽く挙動も安定していて、7段階のスピード調節のおかげでストレスを全く感じさせないつくりです。


有志の方の素晴らしい日本語翻訳も存在しています。
オスマン帝国の復活を夢見たことは？　プロレタリア革命後の日本が歩む道は？
3B政策を完成させたくはないですか？　もしもベルリンに三発目の核が落ちたら？

もちろん、Darkest Hourをプレイしよう！

8701657.review:
Anyone who has spent any time in the Paradox Universe generally knows what they're getting into, so I'll try to keep this short. 

This fan-created spinoff on one the most popular EU/HoI time frames is truly spectacular. It's level of depth is enough to engage the most hardcore simfan, yet accessible enough to catch at least a wandering glare from passersby. 

At the risk of getting in trouble, I'd recommend buying this game, then uninstalling it from Steam, and reinstalling it from it's mother directory. The proliferation of mod material (strangely unavailable in the Steam community last time I checked) only serves to enhance this games playability.

8684396.review:
Darkest Hour differs from Arsenal of Democracy (2010), the other modded product of Hearts of Iron II (2005) in that it expands the total number of provinces and functions as a fully moddable core. While improving Hearts of Iron II, Darkest Hour also includes a number of historical scenarios ranging from Operation Overlord to The Great War (World War I). Although it lacks the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947 or the 1948 Arab-Israeli War offered by Arsenal of Democracy, Darkest Hour provides one of the greatest user modifications ever made -- Kaiserreich.

Available for download on the Paradox forums, the Kaiserreich mod follows the "Legacy of the Weltkrieg." In this scenario, Wilhelm II secured victory in the First World War causing the Allied Powers to fall into disarray, and rendering the Nazis and their rise to power null. Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States all experience turmoil and strife offering the player a large number of decisions -- the UK turns socialist, the US becomes fragmented... Mittelafrika is ruled by Hermann Göring... it's all very engaging.

During my playthrough as Romania in both Arsenal of Democracy and Darkest Hour, Darkest Hour kept most historically accurate during the 1936 Road to War campaign. However it should be noted that Slovakia is formed almost always in Arsenal of Democracy.

I highly recommend Darkest Hour to the armchair general sort of strategy fan. Its successor, Hearts of Iron III, is unfortunately bogged down with unnecessary complexity with an Order of Battle organizational structure that leaves users micromanaging at all times.

You don't have to hassle with finding mods and unlike some mods which either go forward or backwards in time, this does both. If the United States entered the Great war on the side of the Central Powers 
If The British Empire joined the axis in its war against Communism
If the Japanese won at Midway and the Coral Sea 
if Italy managed to take full control of the Mediteranian
If the Soviet Union launched an full scale attack on the Western powers in 1945 
If Nazi Germany had developed the ICBM and the Nuclear bomb 
Then I seriously recomend this game its timeframe expands from the death of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in 1914 to the failed Bay of Pigs in 1962. Durring this period you can play as any nation on the planet from the superpowers of the time such as UK and Germany ( includes all Germanys durring this period Imperial, Wiemar, Nazi, Allied ocuppied to East and West) to the smalest nations on the planet. 
The game's unique Grand Stratagy will be complex at first it is easy to pick up.

7767455.review:
Grand Strategy,play every Nation from the USSR to Peru.Fight in WW1 ,WW2,even into the Cold War Era.
Realtime,pausable,with different Speeds.

Pros:
+++ Lots of Game Depth,Manage your Armies,Generals,Fleets,Air Wings,Ministers,Finance,Trade,Diplomacy.Hardly anything is missing.
+++ Events : historical Events trigger,you can decide if you want to follow History or create an alternate Timeline.Examples: Deny The Soviets their Share of Poland,abort the Attack on Pearl Harbor.
+ Control over internal Politics : You can play a moderate Nazi-Germany,or rekindle the Flames of british Imperialism and attempt to retake the lost american Colonies.
+ Armies and Generals gain Experience ,even develop new Perks
+ Extensive Research Tree: Hundreds of Units and Techs ,ranging from Subs,over encryption to Nukes.
+ Control over the Armies of Allies and Puppet States (If you wish)
++ Many Factors influencing Battles and Movement.
Night/daycycle ,seasonal and hourly Weather Patterns,Experience,added Special Brigades,Unit Types,Terrain,Morale,Envelopment,Supply.
Example: Warfare in Russia gets bogged down during Winter as everything is snowed in.

Cons:
- Timeconsuming , a game can last from one (Scenario) to several hundred Hours (Grand Campaign,World Conquest)



 One of the best Grand Strategy Games

7744834.review: Another great Paradox game. If you enjoy WW2 history and grand strategy this is the game to get. Although focused on WW2 originally, you can play from the Russo-Japanese War (1904-05), WW1, WW2 and into the Cold War time period. It might come off as a bit complicated to begin with, but with a little effort its difficulty gives way to its constant replayability. A massive tech tree, tons of units, hundreds of historical events, this game is incredibly detailed, without being overly complicated. The UI can take a bit of time getting use to, but once you start playing, it comes naturally. For the price tag, this game is really worth it, as you can easily sink a lot more time into this game in terms of replayability (why not go Communist Germany in 1933 for a change?) than it costs.

6800840.review: This game is awesome and the Kaiserreich mod is even better. This is a classic grand strategy game. Command your armies and aim to become to most powerful nation on earth. The game has realistic features like having to decide where to use you industrial capacity, from upgrading your army, to supplying them, to producing new units and factories, and to creating commercial goods to supply you citizens and make your wealth. Another realistic feauture is after moving your troops long distances their organization will be low and they will be not effective in combat. Also the game iis very cheap and the Kaiserreich mod I mentioned earlier is free. Overall it is a great game and I think all strategy lovers should get it.

2020872.review:
Yet another Hearts of Iron 2 Spin-Off, though the best I have played so far.
You can choose from a variety of scenarios, for example the 1914 scenario and the 1933 scenario. Also all of the former "titles" are included in this.
The old manpower-system has been replaced by a Conscription and Mobilization system. Also there are more provinces included, as well as some changes to the units. The new system also has its flaws, but I think it is a good change.
In general you have to say that this game increases the depth of Hearts of Iron 2, while keeping distance to the overpacked Hearts of Iron 3. This is how HoI 3 should have been.
So, to sum it up. You did not like HoI 3 and want a game, which is closer related to the greatest of Hearts of Iron games? Then you can go for this game without any remorse.

2810166.review:
SHORT VERSION : Darkest Hour is the ultimate Hearts of Iron experience, heads and shoulders above all the others (Hearts of Iron 1 & 3, Arsenal of Democracy) thanks to the community improvements. A must have for all wargamers. EDIT : even more so after the last patch (Q1 2014), which refines even more the whole experience.
LONG VERSION : This is the ultimate Hearts of Iron experience. Based on everything that was great in Hearts of Iron 2, better still than the modded version "Arsenal of Democracy" (which in itself is already great), Darkest Hour is a total conversion, expansion, improvement in every single possible way of an already fabulous game.
Not convinced yet? Then try and figure this, because it gets even better : Darkest Hour supports some fantastic mods, and in particular the mother of all mods, Kaisereich. This is a painstakingly researched alternative historical mod, with real (obscure) historical figures coming to life and giving an unprecedented historical research depth in gaming history.
Who hasn't dreamt about running an anarchist-ruled USA, or a Romanov dynasty in a soviet-free Russia?

424964.review: Hearts of Iron 2 with a superbly-made WWI scenario, 1933 scenario, and some gameplay and map changes. The expanded and reorganized tech tree is easier to understand as well, and intelligence/espionage doesn't require quite as sharp an investment now. Unfortunately if you start in 1914 you won't get the 1936 events to fire, but in most games the world is so different by that point it won't matter. The map changes give several small islands multiple zones, so you can have prolonged fighting to control parts of Okinawa or Iwo Jima like what actually happened. An ample amount of alt history options are even explored in the 1914 scenario, which shows that the developers thought of everything. I thought it was really interesting that so many different factions in the Mexican Revolution were represented. In short, it's a very thorough Great War that leaves a lot of interesting possibilites for gameplay. Well worth the money!
